thread.title: College football | Big Ten roundup: Down 52-27, Rutgers wins | Buckeye Xtra Sports
thread.title_full: College football | Big Ten roundup: Down 52-27, Rutgers wins | Buckeye Xtra Sports

title: College football | Big Ten roundup: Down 52-27, Rutgers wins | Buckeye Xtra Sports
text:
Rutgers 55, Indiana 52: Visiting Rutgers turned three fourth-quarter turnovers into touchdowns and Kyle Federico capped an improbable comeback with a 26-yard field goal as time expired in a victory over Indiana on Saturday.
The Scarlet Knights (3-3, 1-2 Big Ten) tied a school record by rallying from a 25-point deficit in the final 201/2 minutes.
Chris Laviano led Rutgers by going 28 of 42 for 386 yards, with three touchdowns and one interception.
But it was a botched snap on a rare Indiana punt that turned the game. Kemoko Turay scooped it up and scored on a 26-yard return to make it 52-39.
Rutgers then took advantage of both of Nate Sudfeld’s interceptions to tie the score at 52. Sudfeld was 32 of 42 for a career-high 464 yards, with four touchdowns for Indiana (4-3, 0-3), which lost its third straight.
 
Wisconsin 24, Purdue 7: Alec Ingold ran for two short scores, Joel Stave passed for 322 yards and host Wisconsin’s stifling defense held Purdue to a season-low 191 yards.
The Badgers (5-2, 2-1) overcame several penalties and other mistakes in the red zone to win on homecoming weekend at Camp Randall Stadium.
Wisconsin led just 10-7 late in the third quarter until the Badgers got two rushing touchdowns during an eight-minute span between the third and fourth quarters.
T.J. Edwards then forced the Boilermakers’ Markell Jones to fumble at Purdue’s 43. Safety Tanner McEvoy pounced on the ball to seal the victory for the Badgers.
Edwards, one of two freshmen starting at inside linebacker for Wisconsin, finished with 16 tackles.
The only score for Purdue (1-6, 0-3) came on David Blough’s 2-yard quarterback keeper in the second quarter.
 
Nebraska 48, Minnesota 25: Tommy Armstrong Jr. bounced back from two bad performances to start Big Ten play, passing for 261 yards and three touchdowns for visiting Nebraska.
Terrell Newby rushed for 116 yards and two first-half scores on just 13 carries for the Cornhuskers (3-4, 1-2), who were reeling from four losses on the opponent’s final offensive play.
This one was a lot less stressful, though Mitch Leidner did his best to keep the Gophers (4-3, 1-2) competitive with career highs in completions (26) and yards (301).
Alonzo Moore, Cethan Carter and De’Mornay Pierson-El were the touchdown targets for Armstrong, who completed only 36 percent of his passes for a total of 234 yards in losses to Illinois and Wisconsin during the previous two weeks.
